text: Travel has made me a better communicator.
Travel has allowed me to be a lot more patient.
Travel.

Travel.
Travel has completely changed my life.

I have found that I have a hard time making
my own decisions especially the final decision.

I am constantly asking people around me for
their opinions or just to make my decisions
for me.

I find that when I travel, especially by myself,
I have to make my own decisions.

There is no one else around me to make those
decisions for me.
I'm forced to do it.

This has really helped me to grow and it has
also helped me to learn a lot more about my
likes and my dislikes.
Travel has made me a better communicator.

Not just learning lingo and languages from
all over the world but it gives me more to
talk about when I meet people.
Everyone has a Heritage.
Everyone comes from somewhere.

When I meet somebody from Spain, even if I
am traveling in Germany, I have been to Spain.

I can now talk to them more about their country
having been there myself.

I think travel has changed me in a lot of
ways.

I am definitely more independent and as funny
as it might be to say, I think I am a lot
smarter.

I know a lot more and maybe I care a lot more
about the world and the events that are happening
because of travel.

It has increased my desire to meet new people
and to go and see all kinds of amazing, awesome
things.

Travel is one of those things that transforms
people and you become a more developed and

well rounded person just by the experiences
that you have.

For me, I have realized that travel has changed
me in the way that anything I have done has
been a result of going out and making it happen.

Nothing is going to be given to you but the
more you put yourself out there, the more

uncomfortable you are willing to be, the more
amazing the experience almost every single
time.

I think travel has changed me in a variety
of ways.

The two most important are: I have a greater
sense of empathy.

When we travel and we go to different places,
you can see how the culture is and how it

is different and how people interact with
each other and for me, when we see people

back home in the States that are maybe new
or just moves or have immigrated, you have

a greater appreciation for what they are going
through and you can relate.

Well the first time that I really started
a big trip, I went to Australia when I was
19 and it was like a world opening.

We were with two friends and we traveled around
the whole continent and it was so amazing

not having an end goal but just the experience
of traveling and meeting new people and learning
new languages.

It was just mind blowing and it completely
opened me up as a person.

Travel has allowed me to be a lot more patient
with life in general because you deal with

a lot of situations where you are having to
wait for stuff or stuff goes wrong or things

are not working out as planned and you are
dealing with transportation getting to and
from places.

Having patience and learning that while time
is valuable you also need to just relax and

let time go and not get so frustrated or upset
or stressed out about the little things that

are happening because in all reality, they
are just little things.

Sort of without even knowing it, travel has
given me the most comprehensive education

I could have ever received and it occurred
to me recently as we were looking at a map

of Leipzig and I saw the highway around the
old town and I was like well obviously that
is where the city wall used to be.

The fact that that is just common knowledge
that pops into my head now is amazing.

I think that travel just starts to fill in
the gaps of knowledge and you start to see

how everything is connected once you see all
the differences and similarities of various
cultures.

When you listen to me talk I sound American
or Canadian.
I'm actually Czech through and through.

I happened to move abroad when I was 13 years
old and went to an international school and
I ended up sounding like this.
I actually speak 4 languages now.
I have lived in 5 cities and I'm 23 so yeah.
It's been quite a game changer.

I remember my first trip to Latin America
and I remember having to catch a bus and the
bus was supposed to leave at about 10:30am.

So I got there at 10:20, had my bags packed,
my tickets printed, all these things and I
get there at 10:20.
Then it was 10:30.

Then it was 10:45 and I thought I had missed
it.

People were not around and I was trying to
find out what was going on.

I found someone who spoke English and they
were like oh no, the bus leaves at 10:30...
No one really knows.
We are waiting for the cook.
He was supposed to be here with his four chickens.
He's not here.
We're going to wait for him.

And that shook up my world because we live
in a world that is very highly organized and

sometimes we get thrown off by small little
things like that.

When things do not arrive on time, when things
do not work out our way.

What travel teaches you are that when things
don't work out how they are planned, it is
usually fine.

You can take that lesson back to real life
and that is actually quite valuable.

Flexibility, tolerance, and patience are very
underrated in this world and those are all
skills that travel teaches you.

Overall, I would say travel made me a happier
person.

As someone who grew up in Germany, which is
quite the perfect place, everything works

here and you can get a job really easy and
we have a good running economy, you get locked
up into this everyday life really quickly.

You start worrying about small issues and
if you go out there and you see how this world

actually works and the problems that are out
there, you start appreciating little things
and you become a happier person.
Well I'm an introvert so... people scare me.

When you go and travel you are forced into
social situations and just being immersed

in people and different languages and stuff,
you have to communicate with them to get around.

You are forced to actually acclimatize into
societies and all these different things and

I think that helped me a lot to become more
adventurous and more confident around people.

When I first started to travel I wasn't really
afraid of the unknown or of the places I went

to but to be all by myself and to have to
handle myself out there, yeah.

Travel changed that and made me feel confortable
with myself more and more.
Travel changes you.
It changes your way of seeing the world.

It gives you a perspective that you did not
have before and it allows you to connect with
people that you never knew existed.

The way it changed me personally is that,
when I traveled on a motorcycle around the

world, I got to meet the local people that
have never seen a tourist before.

People that have never experienced another
culture before.

So when I was able to basically see how people
were living and surviving in different parts

of the world, it was very uniquely enriching
to myself for myself to realize how difficult

the world is for a lot of people and the best
thing I could do was provide a different perspective

and experience and spend a little time with
them.

They say travel makes you more of what you
are but I think travel makes you more of what
you are not.

If you're introverted, you are going to have
to get out of your shell.

You are going to have to expand your comfort
zone and do things that you are not used to.

If you are really extroverted, you are also
going to have to get used to spending some
time alone.

So over the past 7 years, I have found, as
an extrovert, it has made me a little more
introverted.

So now I am more balanced and that is a good
thing.
